messages: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (20:09): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-html/2008Jan/0003.html
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (20:13): wonders why we can't just say they're aliases for each other
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:14): Like <i> and <em>, and <b> and <strong>?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (20:15): No, those actually have useful differences (even though they may be non-existent in practice)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (20:15): I don't think his points are addressed by making <abbr> and <acronym> act the same way
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:15): If the differences are non-existent, doesn't that mean that actually they don't have useful differences?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:15): differences but non-existent. hmm.. :-)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (20:16): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: In a far future, the practice may have changed :)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (20:16): spec vs impl. hmm... :)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (20:16): But we're never, ever going to get agreement on the whole abbreviation nightmare
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:17): Perhaps the important requirement is that a conscientious author should be able to easily work out which element to use in a given situation
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:17): (because otherwise they'll waste time arguing about which is best, since they're too conscientious to just pick one arbitrarily)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (20:18): But it's equally important that the consumer of the information agrees the element is correct

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:21): Consumers will treat the different elements identically, because most authors are not conscientious and will pick one arbitrarily, and consumers can't detect how hard the author thought before deciding on an element, so they can't treat the elements differently
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:22): so consumers don't care, and most authors don't care, so all we can do is make life a little easier for the authors who do care
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:23): (e.g. by keeping them out of arguments over whether SQL is an <acronym> or an <abbr>)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:29): It depends if it is part of MySQL or note :P

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:31): I can imagine that way back when someone started to split hairs about acronyms and abbreviations and someone else thought it would be easier to give in and have both than to deal with the complaints
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:31): and since then countless of hours have been wasted debating correct usage
